questions.question: The base of the skull is primarily formed by which type of ossification?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Endochondral ossification Explanation: There are two major modes of osteogenesis which involve transformation of pre-existing mesenchymal tissue into bone tissue. Membranous Ossification Endochondral Ossification Bone forms directly from mesenchymal tissue without a cartilage intermediate. Cranial vault forms through membranous ossification Bones that undergo membranous ossification: Flat bones of the skull which include bones like the frontal bone parietal bones nasal bones lacrimal bones squamous part of the temporal and occipital bones Maxilla and Mandible (except the condylar process of the mandible, which forms by endochondral ossification). Process : Mesenchymal cells differentiate into osteoblasts, which start forming bone directly by secreting osteoid (bone matrix). This process is characteristic of the bones that contribute to the vault of the skull (calvaria). Bone is formed by first creating a cartilage template, which is then replaced by bone. Cranial base forms though endochondral ossification Bones that undergo endochondral ossification: Base of the skull: Occipital bone ( except the squamous part ) Sphenoid bone Ethmoid bone Petrous part of the temporal bone Condyle of the mandible. Process : In endochondral ossification, a cartilage model of the bone forms first. This cartilage is progressively replaced by bone as it is calcified and invaded by blood vessels, bringing osteoblasts and osteoclasts to reshape the bone. Note-Occipital bone is a membranocartilaginous bone since the part above nuchal line is formed by membranous ossification and rest is formed by cartilagenous ossification

questions.question: Which bones form the weakest point of the skull?

options.A: Frontal, parietal, temporal and sphenoid bones

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Frontal, parietal, temporal and sphenoid bones Explanation: Pterion, the junction where the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones meet is deemed the skull’s weakest part. Skull sutures: Cranial sutures are syndesmosis between the cranial bones. Syndesmosis is fibrous joint between 2 bones. Sutures Meeting Point Coronal suture Junction between the frontal and parietal bones Sagittal suture Junction between the parietal bones Lambdoid suture Junction between the parietal and occipital bones Squamous suture Junction between the parietal and temporal bones Bregma : The point where the sagittal suture and the coronal suture meet. In infants, the anterior fontanelle eventually ossifies and forms the bregma. Lambda : The point where the sagittal suture and lambdoid suture meet. Anterior Fontanelle Posterior Fontanelle A soft spot in a newborn’s skull, located at the junction of the sagittal, coronal and frontal (metopic) sutures. Located at the junction of the sagittal suture and the lambdoid suture. It is diamond-shaped. It is triangular in shape. Typically closes by 18-24 months of age. Typically closes usually by 6 to 8 weeks after birth.

questions.question: Which among the following are pneumatic bones?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) 1,2,3,6,7 Explanation: Labelings in the image are: 1 - Frontal 2 - Sphenoid 3 - Maxilla 4 - Mandible 5 - Parietal 6 - Temporal 7 - Mastoid Pneumatic bones: Frontal (1): Contains sinuses Sphenoid (2): Contains sinuses Maxilla (3): Contains sinuses Temporal (6): Contains ear cavity Mastoid (7): Contains mastoid air cells

questions.question: All among the following would be of adult size at birth except
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Mastoid process Explanation: Mastoid process is absent at birth and is formed only by 2 years of age and mastoid air cells by 6 years of age, whereas mastoid or tympanic antrum are of adult size at birth . Structures at adult size (at birth) Structures NOT at adult size (at birth) Tympanic membrane (Option C) Tympanic cavity Ear ossicles (malleus, incus, stapes) Mastoid (tympanic) antrum (Option B) Internal ear (vestibule, cochlea, semicircular canals) (Option D) Tegmen tympani External ear (auricle/pinna, external auditory canal) Mastoid process (forms by 2 years age) (Option A) (a shorter mastoid process makes the underlying stylomastoid foramen susceptible to injuries during ear surgeries) Mastoid air cells (forms by 6 years age) Eustachian (auditory) tube To remember: Imagine middle ear cavity as a living room, its door (TM), furniture (ossicles), the bedroom (inner ear), and attached toilet (mastoid antrum) are fixed at birth while the garden outside (air cells) and fence (mastoid process) grows Eustachian tube in child: S horter, broader and straight, hence more risk of infection to middle ear following upper respiratory tract infection. Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume 3, Page 30, 31, 268, 318.

questions.question: A patient following a road traffic accident presented to the ED in a confused state. Ecchymosis around the eyes was noted, and CT showed the following. Which of the following does not contribute to the floor of the affected structure?

options.C: Orbital plate of the frontal bone

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Greater wing of sphenoid Explanation: Given clinical scenario and radiological images are suggestive of Anterior cranial fossa fracture. The greater wing of the sphenoid bone does not contribute to the floor of Anterior cranial fossa. Anterior cranial fossa (ACF): Floor Cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone (anterior) (Option A) Superior surface of the anterior part of the body of the sphenoid or Jugum sphenoidale (posterior) Lesser wing of sphenoid (posterior) (Option B) Orbital plate of frontal (on either side) (Option C)

questions.question: Following an RTA, a structure passing through the marked foramen was injured. Which of the following defects is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Loss of sensation over cheek Explanation: Image shows Sphenoid bone with lesser wing and the opening marked is foramen rotundum . Maxillary division of Trigeminal nerve (V2) and emissary vein passes through foramen rotundum and hence loss of sensations of cheek would be the defect seen in this patient. Superior view: Optic canal Superior orbital fissure Foramen rotundum Foramen spinosum Posterior view - Greater wing: Superior orbital fissure Scaphoid fossa Pterygoid fossa Posterior view - Lesser wing: Optic canal Opening of sphenoid sinus Superior orbital fissure Foramen rotundum Pterygoid canal Loss of corneal reflex (Option A): Seen with injury to Ophthalmic division of trigeminal (V2) , which passes through superior orbital fissure . Loss of jaw jerk (Option B): Seen with injury to Mandibular division of trigeminal (V3) , which passes through foramen spinosum . Inability to abduct eye (Option C): Abduction of eye is done by lateral rectus, supplied by Abducens Nerve (VI) which passes through superior orbital fissure .

questions.question: A young female with history of recurrent attacks of pain over medial canthus of eye and cheek presents with chills, rigor, diplopia on lateral gaze and restriction of eye movements. She was diagnosed with PCOS and is on OCPs for the same since 6 months. On examination, edema over eyelids and exophthalmos were noted. Choose the correct combination regarding communication of the most likely structure affected in this patient.

options.A: Transverse sinus through Inferior petrosal sinus
options.B: Internal jugular vein through emissary veins
options.C: Pterygoid plexus through superior petrosal sinus
options.D: Facial vein through superior ophthalmic vein

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Facial vein through superior ophthalmic vein Explanation: Given clinical scenario of restriction of eye movements (III, IV nerve involvement) pain over medial canthus (V1) , pain over cheek (V2 ), diplopia of lateral gaze (VI) with exophthalmos and eyelid edema (venous congestion symptoms) and no history of blindness is suggestive of Cavernous sinus syndrome. CT image showing cavernous sinus thrombosis: Tributaries and communications of cavernous sinus: Tributaries: From the Orbit Superior ophthalmic vein Inferior ophthalmic vein Central vein of the retina (drains into either the superior ophthalmic vein or directly into the cavernous sinus) From the Brain Superficial middle cerebral vein Inferior cerebral veins From the Meninges Sphenoparietal sinus Frontal trunk of the middle meningeal vein Communications Vein/sinus Via Transverse sinus Superior petrosal sinus (Option A) Internal jugular vein Inferior petrosal sinus (Option B) Pterygoid plexus Emissary veins (Option C) Facial vein Superior ophthalmic vein (Option D) Right and Left cavernous sinuses Anterior and posterior intercavernous sinuses

questions.question: Which of the following nerves pass through the internal acoustic meatus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Facial and vestibulocochlear Explanation: Internal acoustic meatus is seen on the floor of the posterior cranial fossa and it transmits facial and vestibulocochlear nerves Posterior cranial fossa: Largest and deepest of the three cranial fossae Houses the hindbrain (cerebellum, pons, and medulla) Structure on the floor of Posterior Cranial Fossa Structures Passing Through Foramen Magnum Medulla Spinal cord Vertebral arteries Transverse Sulcus Transverse sinus Deep Fossae Cerebellar hemispheres Hypoglossal Canal Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) Internal Acoustic Meatus Facial (CN VII) nerve Vestibulocochlear (CN VIII) nerve Aqueduct of Vestibule Endolymphatic duct Jugular Foramen Glossopharyngeal (CN IX) nerve Vagus (CN X) nerve Accessory (CN XI) nerve Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume 3, Page 25-26.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a structure passing through the superior orbital fissure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Facial nerve Explanation: Facial nerve does not pass through the superior orbital fissure. Superior orbital fissure: triangular gap through which the middle cranial fossa connects with the orbit. Part Structures Passing Through Lateral Part Lacrimal nerve (branch of ophthalmic nerve) Frontal nerve (branch of ophthalmic nerve) Trochlear nerve (CN IV) Superior ophthalmic vein Meningeal branch of lacrimal artery Anastomotic branch of middle meningeal artery (anastomoses with recurrent branch of lacrimal artery) Middle Part Upper division of oculomotor nerve (CN III) Lower division of oculomotor nerve (CN III) Nasociliary nerve Abducens nerve (CN VI) Medial Part Inferior ophthalmic vein Sympathetic nerve from plexus around internal carotid artery Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume 3, Page 46, 58.

questions.question: Which of the following nerves does not pass through the common tendinous ring of Zinn?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) None of the above Explanation: Nasociliary nerve (Option A): Passes through the common tendinous ring of Zinn , entering the orbit via the superior orbital fissure within the ring. Abducens nerve (Option B): Also passes through the ring of Zinn via the superior orbital fissure to supply the lateral rectus . Oculomotor nerve (Option C): Divides into superior and inferior divisions , both of which pass through the ring . Hence, all listed nerves do pass through the ring , making "None of the above" the correct answer. Topic Details Common tendinous ring of Zinn Fibrous ring at the apex of the orbit that gives origin to all recti muscles (superior, inferior, medial, lateral) Structures passing through it Superior division of oculomotor nerve (CN III) Inferior division of oculomotor nerve Nasociliary nerve Abducens nerve (CN VI) Sympathetic root of ciliary ganglion Contents of the optic canal (optic nerve and ophthalmic artery) Reference: Vishram Singh’s Textbook of Anatomy, 2nd Edition, Volume 3, Page 285, 319.

questions.question: Match the walls of the orbit with the bones forming it Wall Bone a. Roof 1. Greater wing of sphenoid b. Lateral wall 2. Orbital surface of maxilla c. Floor 3. Orbital plate of frontal d. Medial wall 4. Lacrimal
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) a-3, b-1, c-2, d-4 Explanation: Orbital Wall Structures Forming the Wall Roof Orbital plate of the frontal bone (main part) Lesser wing of the sphenoid (posterior part) Lateral Wall Greater wing of the sphenoid bone (posterior part) Orbital surface of the frontal process of the zygomatic bone (anterior part) Floor Orbital surface of the maxilla (main part) Lower part of the orbital surface of the zygomatic bone (anterolaterally) Orbital process of the palatine bone (posterior angle) Medial Wall From before backward: Frontal process of the maxilla Lacrimal bone Orbital plate of the ethmoid bone Body of the sphenoid bone Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume 3, Page 28, 29.
